snippet: For too long we have thought about prison education almost exclusively in terms of reduced recidivism. But in some sense this is an inadequate metric, neglecting opportunities available to prisoners who pursue and complete higher learning.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column expresses support for prison college education programs, like that at Otisville Correctional Facility in New York State, run by John Jay College of Criminal Justice; holds that such programs provide benefits beyond reduced recidivism, increasing inmates' chances of gaining and keeping employment upon release; laments that such programs have failed to gain state financing.
lead_paragraph: For too long we have thought about prison education almost exclusively in terms of reduced recidivism. But in some sense this is an inadequate metric, neglecting opportunities available to prisoners who pursue and complete higher learning.

headline.main: Prison Program Turns Inmates Into Intellectuals
